chapter.title: Document Manager
chapter.para: Documentation is probably the second most important deliverable in a software project after the software work products themselves. CodeX provides a specific service to manage your project documents.

The CodeX Document Manager is very basic and cannot compare in any way with specialized document repository like DocuShare. It is however very handy to publish documents that are critical to your community of users. Examples are: Installation, Adminstration or User Guide, API documentation, Frequently Asked Questions, etc...
The Document Manager features are as follows:

listitem.para: The CodeX Document Manager can handle any type of document. However we strongly encourage editors to publish their documents in HTML and/or PDF to make it readable quickly and easily.
Documents are stored in groups (or folders). The folders are only one level deep which means you can't have subfolders in a folder.
Documents can be edited on line (if in text or HTML format).
Access control rules can be defined for each document or document group.

section.title: Document Browsing
section.para: To access the Document Manager select the "Docs" item from the Project Menu at the top of the screen of the Project Summary page. The welcome page of the Document Manager shows the list of all the documents published by the project by group.
To read a document simply click on the title.

section.title: Document Submission
section.para: Only project members with the 'Technician' role in the 'User Permissions' matrix can submit documentation. To submit a new document, click on the "Submit New Documentation" link in the Document Manager menu (). Then provide the Document Title, the document description and the body of the text.

The document itself can either be copy-pasted directly in the document text area or uploaded with the help of the "Browse" button and the "Upload" checkbox. Then select a document group from the pull-down menu and click on the "Submit Information" button.
A document has to be attached to a group in any case. This is why CodeX provides a default group called 'Documents' to each project. This default group may renamed without any problem.

tip.title: Tip: Copy-pasted vs. uploaded documents
tip.para: A copy-pasted document will be embedded in a CodeX page, so its appearance will be modified, and some tags like HTML, TITLE, or HEAD will be ignored. An uploaded document, on the opposite, will be displayed "as-is" in the browser window. Another difference is that a copy-pasted document can be edited online, whereas an uploaded document can only be updated by uploading a new version.

section.para: The document title and summary can contain HTML tags. So you can use all sorts of typographic effects as well as pointers to other locations, etc.

tip.title: Tip: Referencing external documents
tip.para: It is sometime convenient to create placeholder documents that actually point to an external location like a DocuShare collection or a DocuShare file for instance. To do this, simply surround the document title with an HREF tag (hyperlink) pointing to the real location elsewhere on the Intranet (an example is given with Document #15 in )

section.title: Document Administration
section.para: The Document Manager provides a number of administration functions like changing a document access permissions, display position or group, creating new document groups, etc.

section.title: Document Publication
section.para: Once a new document has been submitted by a project member with 'Technician' rights on the Document Manager, it is immediately visible on the Document Manager welcome page

section.title: Document Update
section.para: Only members with the 'Administration' right on the Document Manager can modify an existing document.
You can update a document in several ways:

listitem.para: The title, description and document body can be modified. In this case you update the document content
You can change the group (or folder) a document belong to
You can change the document display rank in the document group

section.para: To update a document click on the "Admin" link in the Document Manager menu (). What you see next is the list of all documents of the project sorted by group and by rank. Then choose the document you want to update from the list. Click on the document title to make the document update screen appear. From here you can modify any part of the document, its rank, and the group it belongs to.

section.title: Document Group Management
section.para: In the CodeX Terminology, a CodeX Document group is equivalent to a folder.
To create, delete or change the name of document groups, click on the "Admin" link in the Document Manager menu () and then the "Edit Document Groups" item in the next menu.

To add a new group, use the "Group Name" and "Rank" text fields at the top of the screen and click on the "Create" button. You can also update an existing group by clicking on its name in the group list.
Document groups have a display rank property that defines how document groups are ordered. Document groups with smaller ranks are displayed first.
Access permissions can be defined by clicking on the [Define Permissions] link.
Document groups can be deleted by clicking on the trash icon in the group list. Only empty document groups may be deleted: move or delete documents that belong to a group before trying to delete it.

section.title: Setting Access Permissions
section.para: Setting document access permissions is very similar to setting file access permissions (): you need to create user groups, and assign those user groups to documents or document groups.

By default, document and document groups have no specific access permissions: access to all documents is granted to anybody, including anonymous user. However, in some cases, you might want to limit the users allowed to read your documentation, e.g. when it contains confidential data. In these specific cases, you can restrict access permissions to your documents to specific user groups. See for more information on user groups.
Document groups and document permissions are enforced at two different levels:

listitem.para: Document List: When a user is not granted access to a document, then it is not listed in the 'Docs' main page, so s/he does not know that the document exists.

Display: If a user finds or forges a display link for an unauthorized document, the download will still fail. The system systematically re-checks for permissions when documents are requested for download.

section.para: Access permissions can be defined at two different levels: document groups and documents:

listitem.para: By clicking on 'Define Permissions' on the "Edit Document Groups" screen (see ), a project member with the 'Document Manager Admin' right (see ) can attach access permissions to any existing document group.

The document group permissions edition page lists all the project user groups. Simply select the user groups that will be allowed to display documents from the document group and press submit. You may select several groups at the same time if needed. If you press 'Reset To Defaults', the access permissions to this package will be reset, so any user will be able to download it.

Note that each time you edit permissions associated to a document group, the previous values are reset. So, for instance, if you grant permissions to 'project members', submit, then want to grant permissions to another group, do not forget to select also 'project members' the second time, or they will not have access to your document group.
Permissions attached to a document group apply to all documents that belong to this group. But you may also set different permissions to specific documents (see below).
If you need finer grained access control to your documents, you can also define permissions at the document level.

The procedure is similar to the document group permissions definition. Simply click on 'Define Permissions' on the document manager 'admin' page (see ) to attach access permissions to a document. Then select allowed user groups and submit.

If you do not specify any access permissions for a document (or reset them to default), it inherits the access permissions from the document group it belongs to. However, when you define a permission for a document, then it overrides the permissions defined for the group.
The permissions set for the document can be either stricter or less strict than the group permissions.

tip.title: Tip: Updating existing permissions
tip.para: There is a shortcut to update document and document group permissions. For project administrators or document manager administrators, the main 'Docs' page displays small lock icons next to protected documents and groups. Simply click on the lock to update permissions for the corresponding object.
